do

mkdir -p new/$rep && cp $REPLY new/$rep/
done < filesource

Explanations about Options.-w:
Write files to the standard output in the specified archive format. When no file
 operands are specified, standard input is read for a list of pathnames with one per
 line without any leading or trailing <blanks>.
Explanations about Options.-d:
Cause files of type directory being copied or archived, or archive members of type
 directory being extracted, to match only the directory file or archive member and
 not the file hierarchy rooted at the directory.

so_60016712: find and copy files and directories

nl2bash_9582: Print mv commands to rename all files under current directory by formatting the filenames with the sed scripts '\''s/^([^-]*)-\s*([^\.]*)/\L\1\E-\2/'\'', '\''s/ /_/g'\'' and '\''s/_-/-/g'\''
Top-3 Scripts:
so_60016712: find test -type f -mtime -1 -exec bash -c '
    src=("$@")
    dst=("${@/#test/backup}")
    mkdir -p "${dst[@]%/*}"
    for i in "${!src[@]}"; do
        cp "${src[i]}" "${dst[i]}"
    done
' _ {} +

Explanations about Options.-name:
This option is supported, but POSIX conformance depends on the POSIX conformance of
 the system's fnmatch(3) library function. As of findutils-4.2.2, shell
 metacharacters (`*', `?' or `[]' for example) will match a leading `.', because
 IEEE PASC interpretation 126 requires this. This is a change from previous
 versions of findutils.
